awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: The Economic and Behavioral Effects of a Value Added Tax: Evidence from Firm-level Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The Value-Added Tax (VAT) is a tax on consumption. It is one of the youngest yet among the most important sources of government revenue. The VAT was first introduced in 1967 in Brazil and Denmark and by 2013 more than 160 countries had adopted it. One of the key reasons for the rapid adoption of the VAT is that it is believed to be an efficient tax instrument. That is, a VAT does not create distortions in firms' production decisions, implying that government can raise revenue with minimum cost and without impeding economic growth. A key weakness of this prediction is that it is based on an environment with perfect tax compliance and perfect tax enforcement, which is often violated in practice. Thus, whether the VAT is an efficient tax system is ultimately an empirical question. There is, however, surprisingly little evidence evaluating these efficiency properties of a VAT. This proposed research uses a commercial database that contains information on millions of firms for up to 10 years, to estimate the causal impact of a VAT on firm' growth (e.g, output, employment, investment spending, and productivity) and firms' behavioral responses (e.g, under-reporting of the revenue or over-reporting of the cost to claim undue tax credit).

Randomized experiments are considered the gold standard in studying the effect of a treatment. However, due to ethical or economic reasons, most of the social and economic policies (including a VAT) are not implemented randomly. The PI uses Regression Discontinuity Designs (RDD) to create the conditions for a local random experiment by exploiting behavior around a registration threshold imposed by law. This research makes several contributions. It analyzes the effects of a VAT by exploiting a VAT rule that creates the conditions for a local random experiment. Second, most of the previous studies on the effects of a VAT use aggregate data that often mask great deal of variability. Isolating causality using aggregate data is difficult due to many omitted variables that can affect growth. The PI uses rich micro data that allow establishment of a tighter link between a VAT and relevant outcomes. Third, there is a voluminous literature on firms? behavioral responses to direct taxation such as the corporate income tax. However, the literature on firms? behavioral responses to the indirect taxation such as a VAT is small. This study contributes to this small but important literature. Finally, at present, the full impact of a VAT is poorly understood. The results from this study will provide insights on how to improve the administration, enforcement, and ultimately the effectiveness of a VAT system.

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, we have completed the project exploring taxpayers' responses to the Value-Added Tax System in France. This project was an integral part of the doctoral dissertation of the Co-PI.

The Value-Added Tax (VAT) is a tax on consumption. It is one of the youngest yet among the most important sources of government revenue. The VAT was first introduced in 1967 in Brazil and Denmark and by 2013 more than 160 countries had adopted it. One of the key reasons for the rapid adoption of the VAT is that it is believed to be an efficient tax instrument. This project used NSF grant to purchase Orbis, a commercial database from Bureau Van Dijk that contains information on millions of French firms for up to 10 years. The rich nature of the database allowed the PIs to estimate the causal impact of a VAT on firms' growth (e.g., output, employment, investment spending, and productivity) and firms' behavioral responses (e.g., under-reporting of the revenue or over-reporting of the cost to claim undue tax credit). The PIs used Regression Discontinuity Designs (RDD) to create the conditions for a local random experiment by exploiting the VAT rule requiring all firms with annual sales revenue above EUR 85, 000 to register for the VAT.

The results suggest that the VAT has boosted private capital accumulation in affected firms. Over the period analyzed, tangible fixed assets are about 10 percent higher in the affected firms compared to similar but unaffected firms. However, we find a negligible impact of the VAT on firms' productivity and input costs. We also find that the impact of a VAT is heterogeneous across the sectors of the economy. The hotel and restaurant industries had the most meaningful effects, with positive and significant impacts on both productivity and investment; they also reported higher material costs compared to similar firms just below the VAT threshold. For the rest of the sectors, we find that the VAT increases firms' spending on capital accumulation, but we find no significant impact of the VAT on firms' productivity or input cost.

The effect of a VAT is an important public policy question. Many countries have implemented a VAT and others, including the United States, are studying the possibility of adopting such a tax system. The results of this project inform the debate in these countries, facilitating evidence-based discussion on reforming existing VAT system or implementing a new VAT system.
